The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HASELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.

div.head: THE FLEETS AT BREST.
div.p: The visit of the British Fleet to Brest and the hearty reception accorded to our sailors by their gallant hosts bring into a very pleasant prominence the question of our relations with our Continental neighbours. It was not always so. The period of misunderstanding and ill-feeling, though it may take an effort to recall it in the light of the present rapprochement, is still so near to us that an element of surprise inevitably mingles with the thankfulness that we feel for the complete and, we hope, permanent change. For this change we are indebted not a little to the tact of our King, so amiably reciprocated by the visit of M. Loubet; and both nations have felt and expressed their pleasure at the diplomatic strength given to the union.

Under the present circumstances the visit of our ships has a peculiar interest. The Continent of Europe contains explosive elements, to say nothing of the causes of mutual offence which are so widely scattered over the face of Europe and Asia, which no amount of friendly words render innocuous. The strong man

armed must continue to be the ultimate ga- rantee for the safety of his house. But it is possible to distinguish between nations whose interests and whose ambitions are fundamentally hostile to ours, and nations with whom we have only some passing though irritating occasion of difference. And we must remember that for nearly five and thirty years it has been the object of one of the Great Powers of Europe to sow the seeds of discord between her rivals, and to profit by maintaining a perpetual state of irritation between peoples who might other- wise have rested in peace and tranquillity.

The ingenious attempt to weaken the entente which even the peacable M. Jaurés denounced with the vigour of a militant patriot should be as much a lesson to us, as were the earnest and successful efforts made by France to keep the peace without sacrificing her prestige or her exceptional position in Morocco. Whatever diplomatic success German interference in Morocco may have won, the understanding between France and England is in no way weakened and the visits of the Squadrons are, we hope, a sign that external interference can only tighten the bonds between the two great democracies of Western Europe. Admiral May's message to the French Minister of Marine expresses with nautical frankness what politicians have at times ignored, viz., the community of interests between the two nations who find themselves face to face with a formidable and hungry rival.

Although we are within a few weeks of the centenary of the last great sea fight between an English and a French fleet, and although in another ten years there will have been a full century of peace to seperate us from the great French war, yet it cannot be denied that peace between France and England has often been in sore peril during the intervening years. Indeed it seems but yesterday-and it is but little more than two years ago-that war was openly talked of between the two countries. And yet there can be no possible doubt as to the absolute sincerity of th joy with which both nations have welcomed the happy change which has come over the spirit of their mutual relation. The population of Brest and the crowds of visitors to the grim, grey old Breton port are as glad to see their British guests as the people of Portsmouth will be to welcome the French sailors when they pay the return visit. The fact is that there is no good reason, at this time of day why England and France should not live in peace and amity-while there are diverse very weighty reasons why they should. Nowhere, too, is that more keenly felt than on the French coast, whose people have ever had to bear the brunt of an English war. So Brest is right glad to-day-and so are we.

div.head:
TROUBLES IN CRETE.
MARTIAL LAW THREATENED.

div.p: Reinforcements are leaving for Canea. (H.)

The foreign Consuls in Crete have inter- viewed the insurgent leaders, and declared that, while the rebellious movement continues, it will be impossible to modify the status of the island. They promised to introduce the widest reforms, and demanded that the insurg- ents should lay down their arms within fifteen days, otherwise they might be forced to apply martial law. (Reuter.)
Before leaving Paris, Admiral May wrote a letter to Mr. Thomson, Minister of Marine, saying that the "entente cordiale" was a real entente as French and English interests are identical (Havas.)
Great Britain and Spain will join the Mo- rocco Conference, provided that the programme be communicated to them in advance. (Reuter.)
M. Villaverde, Spanish Conservative states- man, and ex-Premier, is dead (Reuter.)

Senor Villaverde made his mark in the first Silvela Administration in 1899 as the kind of statesman Spain needs. While his chief was engaged in sketching ecstatic visions of the Spain of the future the Finance Minister devoted himself to the securing of sufficient revenue to meet the national obligations and carry on the system of Government. The new supplies came in, but his efforts to se- cure a permanent reduction of outlay provoked violent hostility both in the army and navy, nor was this hostility bought off by the retire- ment of the Finance Minister, whose most important success was the raising of a loan of £48,000,000 to pay off the floating debt. His successors were only too glad to attempt in detail what he had endeavoured to achieve on a large scale. Persisiting in his mission to impress on his countrymen a rigorous system of economy Senor Villaverde gained so much ground that he was invited to form a Cabinet in 1901 and though unsuccessful that year became Prime Minister in 1902, resigning in the summer of 1903.

div.head:
A RUSSIAN ROUT.
BRISK FIGHTING.
RUSSIANS DRIVEN NORTHWARDS.

div.p: Marshal Oyama reports brisk fighting in Sakaline. The Japanese drove out the Russians from Vladimirovka and Blijineye on the 10th inst. The Russians retired nortward to a fortified position at Dalineye, which the Japan- ese stormed and carried on the 11th, completely routing the russians on the 12th. (Reuter)

The Russians in the north of Korea are gra- dually being driven northwards. They now hold only two positions south of Tumen, viz., Fumen and Moshan. The latest information, however, reports the advent southward of a large force from Vladivostok, but it is believed that it will halt at Notiefok, north of Tumen, and make a resolute stand there against the Japanese advance. (Reuter.)
The rainy season has set in Manchuria, preventing movements on a large scale. (R)

div.head:
THE PEACE CONFERENCE.
M. WITTE'S APPOINTMENT.

div.p: Japan is gratified by the appointment of M. Witte, who will leave St. Petersburg on Wednesday and proceed to New York via Cherbourg. (Reuter)

Yesterday, Mr. Takahira visited President Roosevelt at Oyster Bay in connection with the details of the peace conference. He ex- pressed his gratification at the appointment of M. Witte, who is an able man, and who will lend confidence and weight to the conclusions of the conference. (Reuter)
M. Witte, Russian peace plenipotentiary, will leave for Washington on the 19th inst. (Havas)

div.head:
RUSSIAN PEASANT DISTURBANCES.
METHODS OF REPRESSION.

div.p: Reuter's Agency learns from Odessa that the authorities are acting severely to repress the peasant disturbances. At Kherson 1,060 people have been arrested, and in the district of Parutino the prisoners have been terribly beaten by the Cossacks, and two have succumb- ed. Drastic measures have been taken, which are apparently successful. (Reuter)

div.head:
DISAFFECTION OF COSSACKS.
MUTINY NEAR LODZ

div.p: A company of Cossacks at Zgierz near Lodz mutinied, complaining of their food, and demanding arrears of pay. They were surround- ed and disarmed. This is the first time that Cossacks have shown dissafection. (Reuter)

div.head:
M. DEROULEDE DEMANDS JUSTICE
LEAVES SPAIN FOR AUSTRIA

div.p: M. Deroulède has refused the pardon, and declines to return unless he receive justice. (R)
M. Deroulède is leaving for Austria. He has visited the King and Queen Christina, who received him cordially.
It is stated here that, in compliance with the request of Persia, a commission of Russian sugar specialists will start in August to examine the possiblity of the cultivation of beet-root in Persia.
Carlisle election in place of the late Speaker, Mr. Gully. Mr. Chance, Liberal 3,616; Mr. Sanderson, Conservative, 2,585. (Reuter.)
The Caledonien, from China to Marseilles, badly grounded near here, has been pulled off by H.M.S. Perseus, which is towing her to Djibouti. (Reuter)
The Duke of Connaught announced at Bisley that he intends to make tours of inspection in South Africa and Canada. (Reuter)
Scotland won the Elcho Shield. (Reuter)
Eton v. Harrow drawn. Surrey beat Wor- cestershire by 343 runs. The rest of the matches for this day were drawn. (R)

div.head: TO POINT A MORAL. I.-
div.p: A youth named Sabir Khalil, aged 16 years, attempted a free ride on a tram, with the result that, in leaping off to avoid the guard, he broke his left leg.

div.head: TO POINT A MORAL. II.-
div.p: A boy named Hanna Bali, while flying a kite from the roof of a house in the El Baktaria quarter, fell through an opening and broke his right arm, besides sustaining minor injuries
LIFONTI'S MUSIC STORES have been removed from the premises in Cherif Pasha street to the new Lifonti Building in Rosetta road. The inauguration of the new establishment will take place in a few days.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL.
div.p: -21 vessels passed through the Canal on the 13th and 14th int., 16 of which were British, 1 French, 4 German. The receipts for the two days were frs. 614,920.32, making the total from the 1st inst. frs. 4,127,890.17

div.head: HOTEL BEAU-RIVAGE.-
div.p: A successful small dance was given at this delightfully situated hotel on Saturday evening. The new floor which has been laid on the terrace was in the pink of condition, and the music was supplied by the string band of the Royal Berks. Before the dance a large number of dinners were served on the terrace.

div.head: SAN STEFANO CASINO.-
div.p: The small dance given at the Casino on Saturday was very animated, a large number of people staying after dinner. Yesterday morning's instrumen- tal concert on the terrace was very largely attended, as usual. Massenet's fist suite d'orchestre was well executed, as was also Beethoven's fifth symphony, which was greatly applauded. Next Sunday, three singers from Milan will make their debut. THeir repertoire consists of selections from Italian operas. They will by accompanied by the orchestra.

div.head: EDEN MUSIC HALL FRACAS.-
div.p: Last Friday, at about midnight, a quarrel broke out in the Eden Music-hall. It appears that the attitude of a part of the audience towards one of the artistes provoked heated replies; a scuffle ensued, and the confusion was increased by one of the performers, a Frenchman, falling in a fit. Had matters terminated ther, there would have been nothing further to comment upon, but we regret to state that Saghco- lagassi Lynn of the Police and Fire Brigade, who was present, seems to have made con- fusion worse confounded by unnecessarily drastic measure, which included the calling in of a number of policemen who were order- ed to draw their sword bayonets. Though it seems, so far, that no serious injuries were received in the affray, some French and other foreign subjects were hustled, and M. Gaston, M. Sinadino's chauffeur, brought away some nasty bruises. An inquiry was opened at the Gouvernorat at 3 p.m. on Sat- urday, a delegate of the French Consulate, to which complaints had been addressed, being present. After a close investigation of the facts it was finally decided that all papers re- ferring to the affair should be forwarded at once to the Ministry of the Interior, and that Saghcolagassi Lynn should in the meantime be suspended from the exercise of his functions.

div.head: THE FRENCH FETE.
THE CAIRO CELEBRATIONS
div.p: The festivities held in Cairo on Friday last in celebrations of the 14th of July, were, as we reported on Saturday last, a greater success than ever. The Sharia Kamel, the principal street of the Capital, assumed an appearance of unusual gaiety throughout the day, and though none of the shops were closed, it appeared to be an occasion of holiday-making for many of the French patriots. A number of the larger houses and establishments were de- corated with the tricolour, and after dark many of them were simply but effectively illuminat- ed. Amongst the chief of these we might men- tion the offices of the Gas Company, Shepheard's and the Continental HOtels, the French Agency and French Consulate, and the Cercle Fran- çais.

Receptions were held at 9 in the morning at the French Consulate by M. Bosquet, and at the Agency by M. Bonin, and it is needless to add that both of these notabilities received their many callers with their usual grace and courtesy.

Towards sunset Sharia Kamel became great- ly crowded, and when the triumphal arch which had been erected at the Boulac entrance to the gardens was illuminated, all the passers-by stood still to admire it. From the centre of the arch colourless electric globes had been arranged in rays, on the top of the two columns were similar lights set in circles, and between them hung chains of coloured globes.

On entering the gardens one passed along an avenue of short columns, each one of which, bearing the French arms, was brilliantly lighted, and this led to the special pavilion which had been erected for the reception of the guests by M. Bonin, who is representing M. de la Boulinière during the latter's absence.

To describe the scene which here met the eye is a task of no little difficulty. The pavilion was surrounded by a long string of Chinese lanterns, the ends of which were attached from the roof to columns some 8 feet in height. The pavilion was lit by electricity and its walls were prettily decorated with the French arms. To the right was a special open-air theatre which had been erected for a variety perfor- mance by which the troupe of the Nouveautés attracted many people, and also two bandstands for the accomodation of the bands of the Inniskilling Fusiliers and the Egyptian Cavalry, and between these two stands was an asphalted space which was reserved for dancing later in evening. In front of these gas jets had been arranged in various designs, which afforded an exceedingly pretty contrast to the Chinese lanterns, and on each side of the theatre was an arch of coloured electric globes.

M. Bonin, on his arrival, was met at the gates by the members of the committee and was greeted by the playing of the "Marseillaise" by the Egyptian Cavalry Band. On his ap- proaching the pavilion the band of the Innis- killing Fusiliers greeted him with the same strains, and as he entered, the string band in attendance continued the hymn. Next followed the Khedivial Anthem and after that "God save the King," both of which were played by the three bands in succession.

The British nation was not only very fully represented by those who had come primarily in an official capacity, but nearly every Eng- lishman who is in Cairo had come to take part in the fête, and the bond of union which the "Entente Cordiale" has established between the two races was in great evidence.
The large number of invited guests were received by M. Bonin with his usual cordiality, and every hospitality was pressed upon them by the members of the French colony who assisted him.

The two military bands performed their task with great credit, and their varied pro- grammes were greatly enjoyed by all present. The Nouveautés troupe, under the direction of M. Lauri, gave their usual performance, Mlle Mary Fleur, Mlle Liliane and M. Stephano being especially deserving of the applause with which they were wlecomed.

The pyrotechnic display was commenced about 11.30 p.m. It was exceedingly unfor- tunate that the fireworks had become damp, and that in consequence the set-pieces were by no means so good as they should have been in their effect. Heavy clouds of smoke almost hid them from view and choked the spectators, but the smaller pieces left nothing to be desired either as regards brilliancy or noise caused by the explosion, which was almost deafening. After the display of fireworks had been concluded, dancing was indulged in by many, the music being supplied by the military bands, and this was kept up for a cosiderable time. Two o'clock witnessed the departure of a large number of people, but it was not until after 4 p.m. that Cairo had assumed its usual early morning calm.

The committee to whom had been entrusted the work of organisation must indeed feel very happy at the success with which their efforts were crowned. All present enjoyed themselves immensely, and the unanimous opinion was that a more enjoyable evening could not have been wished for. We therefore do not hesitate to offer the committee, on behalf of our readers, their best thanks for the admirable way in which they performed their task and our heartiest congratulations on the results

The police authorities must also be con- gratulated upon the order which was maintain- ed among the large crowds which were attracted by the illuminated arch, and the streams of people which poured into the garden until a late hour. The carriage traffic was enormous, but the people were confined to the footpaths as far as possible, and we believe that in spite of the great crush no accident occurred.

div.head: THE ST. KILDA.
INCIDENT AT PORT SAID.
div.p: The Marseilles correspondent of the "Jour- nal" sends the particulars of a statement made to him by the captain of the St. Kilda, who arrived at that port on board the steamer Egypt, aecompanied by the oficers and the European crew of his vessel. After describing how the St. Kilda was sunk by the Dnieper and the crew were taken on board the cruiser, the captain of the British steamer continued:

"On our arrival at Port Said...the commander of the Dnieper told us that he in- tended to take us to Russia. 'We shall only wait to take in coal,' he said,'before proceeding on our voyage. You are our prisoners.' But one of us managed to escape, and informed the British consul of what had happened. The captains of two English men-of-war, the Lancaster and the Suffolk, came on board the Dnieper with the British Consul, and demanded our release.

"The commander of the Dnieper refused to accede to the demand of the Consul, who left the ship, accompanied by th ecommanders of the Suffold and the Lancaster, after stating that special measures would be taken if the British subjects were not set at liberty within an hour. A quarter of an hour later, when the Lancastor raised anchor as if she were about to approach the Dnieper, the Russian commander gave us permission to leave the ship, taking with us our luggage."

div.head: RUSSIAN TRANSPORT AT SUEZ
div.p: Suez, Sunday

The Russian transport Anadyr arrived at Suez yesterday afternoon and entered the Canal at 10 p.m. bound to Libau. This vessel had been following Admiral Rodjestvensky's squadron, and although she did not take an active part in the great naval battle, she was present when the attack began and sub- sequently managed to escape, after rescuing several Russian officers and men from a sinking cruiser, who are now on board.

div.head: BRITISH BATTLESHIPS AT SUEZ.
div.p: Suez, Sunday
H. M.'s battleships Ocean, Centurion, Albion, and Vengeance arrived at Suez at daybreak this morning from the China station and entered the Canal at 10.30 this forenoon,

div.head: THE 14TH JULY AT SUEZ.
div.p: Suez, Saturday

The frenche fête this year was a great success at Port Tewfik owing to the excellent arrangements made by the committee. At 5 p.m. a Gymkhana commenced with chil- dren's races, and subsequently several other amusing games took place. Shortly after 9 o'clock in the evening, a dance was held and was attended by almost all the European community. It was gaily kept up to a late hour, to the strains of a string band. The fireworks, combined with the brilliantly illu- minated avenue, made a fine show.

div.head: CATTLE PLAGUE.
div.p: During the week ending the 15th inst., 33 deaths from cattle plague were notified in Egypt. Of these cases one occured at Cairo, one at Port Said, one at Facous, 6 at Hehia, 14 at Chibin el-Kom, one at Ghizeh, and 10 at Beni-Souef. The number of deaths during the corresponding period last year was 874. The total number of deaths since the commence- ment of the epidemic amounts to 147,354, distributed as follows:-Gouvernorats, 893; Lower Egypt, 54,214, Upper Egypt 92,247.

div.head: BUBONIC PLAGUE.
div.p: The weekly bulletin published by the Sa- nitary Administration concerning bubonic plague reports the notification of 12 cases of bubonic plague during the week ending Satur- day last. Of these cases, 7 occurred at Alexandria, one at Kafr Zayat, 2 at Achmoun, and 2 at Damanhour. Nine deaths were reported, namely, 4 at Alexandria, one at Port Said, 2 at Achmoun, one at Damanhour, all of which are natives, and one European at Damanhour. Five cures have been effected and there remains 22 cases under treatment, namely, 2 Europeans and 6 natives at Alexandria, 7 natives at Achmoun, 4 at Toukh, one at Zifta, one at Kafr Zayat, and 1 at Damanhour.

Since the issue of this bulletin we learn that the case which occurred at Kafr Zayat has ended fatally, and that another member of the same household has contracted the disease. Both of these cases, we are told, are from Da- manhour.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Mors liner Tabor sailed yesterday morning for Havre viâ Malta with passengers, mails, and cargo of beans.
The Messageries Maritimes S.S. Portugal, from Marseilles, passed the Straits of Messina on Saturday and is due here to-morrow morning.

div.head: THE HAMADE INCIDENT.
ITS POLITICAL BEARINGS.
div.p: The corrupt administration of the late Vali of Beyrout had culminated in the sanguinary skirmish between Christians and Moslems two summers ago that threatened to develop into a wholesale massacre. The advent of the present Vali, Khalil Pasha, with all his moderation, integrity, and general enlightenment, did not soon dissipate the restlessness that continued in Beyrout after the fanatical outbreak, and it took some time before a normal course of things was re-established and a reasonable understand- ing between Christians and Moslems was attained. But Beyrout seems to be doomed to continual unrest. We had scarcely begun to taste the quiet delights of security when the Hamadé incident came to trouble our peace.

At one time it seemed to be the foreboding of a reign of terror, for the arrest of Hamadé Bey was followed by the ransacking of the Moslem Onsi library, and a few Moslem and Christian houses suspected of containing revolutionary documents. This attempt on per- sonal liberty, which even in Turkey is now considered a sacred right, has been deeply resented by all thinking Moslems. The recent sweeping movement of racial independence on the part of the Arabs in Yemen, with all its glamour of ancient Moslem glories, was calcula- ted naturally to evoke strong though silent sympathies in the hearts of their Moslem kinsmen on this side. The educated are begin- ning to realise the unfitness of the Turk to rule them, and chafe against his haughty demeanour towards them, while they resent his exclusive monopoly of Government offices. As for the poor and illiterate, they cannot but feel a stifled hatred of those who so mer- cilessly oppress and bleed them. But the lack of unity and homogeneity of race have always barred the possibility of any organised move- ment for freedom, while the adoption by the diplomatic Turk of the faith of the conquered, if only in form, has always acted as a strong magnet that drew Islam to the Sultanante, de- spite the repellent forces of despotism and oppression.

Yet the recent events in Yemen have chang- ed the aspect of things and inaugurated a new era in the political life of Islam, having served to stir latent dreams in the bosoms of the Syrian Arabs and fuse the heterogeneous elements of Islam in Syria into one common feeling of religoius and racial solidarity, that only blood and the old fascination of the sword and the emblematic banner could evoke. The tie of religion that has so far given the illusion of brotherhood between the Turks and Arabs (otherwise so far apart in language and genius), has at last become loosened, and the process of disruption is being slowly accom- plished at least in feeling, if not in fact. For- merly, no Moslem would confess to his hatred of the Turk or his wish for the disappearance of his rule, but lately such confessions have not been uncommon and have been more freely made to me as an Englishman and stranger on his travels. This ferment could not elude the attention of even the dull and obtuse Turk, whose suspicions were more especially aroused by the recent passive demonstration of sympa- thy on the part of the Syrian soldiers in Yemen. Wherefore the Government's vigilance has lately been redoubled, and a greater de- mand for the service of the spy manifested.

The Hamadé incident symbolises the wanton system of espionage by which the Govern- ment seeks to check the anti-Turk movement. Hamadé Bey, though a quiet, inoffensive and faitful Moslem, has been arrested chiefly because of his relationship with the late Sheikh Mohamed Abdou, the great exponent of Moslem liberalism. During his stay in Egypt as a zealous steamship agent he naturally endeavoured wherever he went to use all his persuasive powers to induce the Egypt- ians to pass the summer in the Lebanon. This laudable manifestation of a sense of duty was so distorted and misinterpreted by the salaried spies and calumniators of the capital that it ended by eliciting an impe- rial iradé of arrest. The officials charged with the communication of the order of arrest were friends of Hamadé Bey, and as the latter landed and greeted them with unsus- pecting friendliness they felt embarrassed and finally explained to him the position with the utmost kindness, while they led him off to the seraglio to undergo an interrogation and cross-examination at the hands of a committee formed ad hoc. In the meantime his luggage was seized and ransacked with diligent care, but the most obnoxious thing they could find was the well-known commen- tary on the Koran by the late learned Sheikh Mohamed Abdou. The Vali, a reasonable and well-meaning gentleman, did his best throughout to act in an equitable manner, but in delicate situations of this kind pru- dence sometimes dictates the sacrifice of cer- tain qualms of the conscience, and it is very doubtful whether the incident would have closed so happily with the relase of Hamadé Bey on the eighth day from his arrest, had not friends of the prisoner interceded successfully with the authorities at Constanti- nople.

div.head: (CYPRUS.) THE OLYMPUS HOTEL.
div.p: On Mount Troodos : 6,000 feet above sea level. Perfect climate. Magnificent scenery. Season May to October. For inclusive terms and information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, the General Manager, Cyprus Hotel Company, Limassol, Cyprus.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Rear-Admiral Sir Massie and Lady Blomfield were among the passengers who arrived by the Austrian Lloyd's S.S. Cleopatra this morning.
Owing to the postponement of the departure of the Moss boat, Mr. and Mrs. Gould will not leave for England till to-morrow.
Mr. F.G. Freeman, H.B.M.'s Vice-Consul, returned from leave on Saturday last.
Herr von Mohl, German Commissioner of the Public Debt, has arrived from Europe by the Italian mail. He is accompanied by Miss von Mohl.
Mr. C. Higgins, 3rd secretary to H.B.M.'s Agency, arrived from Cairo on Saturday.
We regret to announce the death, which took place on July 1 at Brockmeir-on-Wye, of the little daughter of Lt.-Col. Stanton, Governor of Khartoum, who had twice been to Khartoum with her father.

We also regret to announce that Mr. Baehler, the well-known and popular manager of Shepheard's and the Ghezireh Palace Hotel, has suffered two terrible bereavements during the past week. His father died a week ago and at 10 a.m. yesterday Mme. Baehler passed away quietly at Leysin-sur-Aigle, Switzerland. Mr. Baehler's countless friends will join us in the expression of the most heartfelt sympathy for him in his double affliction.

The following visitors are staying at the Beau-Rivage Hotel, Ramleh: Mr. and Mrs. L. Zoucas and family, Mr. and Mrs. W. Page, Mr. and Mrs. H. Daffa and family, Mr. L.F. div.head: QUESTIONS MUNICIPALES
La gestion des Finances
L'abaissement de la ligne de Ramleh
div.p: Depuis trois mois les comptes-rendus de la Délégation et de la Commission nous donnent d'interminables listes de crédits votés par nos édiles. Comme c'est la ville qui paye, il ne serait que juste de la part de la Municipalité d'ajouter à chaque chef de crédit, le motif qui l'a occasionné, mais le secrétaire se contente invariablement d'enregistrer les sommes votées, sans donner aucune raison explicative des dépeuses.

Nous avons d'abord cru à un dédain systé- matique du public et de la presse. La raison de toutes ces dépenses existait sans aucun doute, mais qu'était-il le besoin de fournir des explications au contribuable, une fois que celui-ci avait payé, son rôle n'était-il pas fini?.

Voilà ce que nous nous disions lorsqu'il nous revint à notre plus grande stupéfaction que non seulement la plupart des crédits sont pro- posés à la Commission et votés par celle-ci sans aucun examen, mais qu'encore ils sont admis par la Délégation et élaborés par les services techniques sans aucun argument en faveur de leur nécessité ou même de leur simple utilité.

Dernièrement encore la Commission Munici- pale a voté un fort crédit pour l'abaissement du niveau de la ligne du Chemin de fer de Ramleh jusqu'à l'Ibrahimieh, travail pour lequel elle ne fournit aucune explication plau- sible et qui aura un effet déplorable sur l'a- venir de ce quartier.
Nous reproduisons à titre de curiosité la note des services techniques à ce sujet.

div.head: Note au sujet de l'abatissement de la ligne du Chemin de fer de Ramleh jusqu'à l'Ibrahimieh
div.p: "Il résulte des entrevues que j'ai eues, sui- vant l'ordre de M.l'Administrateur, avec MM. Lumbroso, Salvago et Jacot, que le coût de transfert des voies existantes entre le Pont de Chatby et la tranchée de l'Ibrahimieh est de L.E.1.350."

"L'Alexandria and Ramleh Railway Com- pany accepterait ce transfert et serait disposée de supporter la moitié des frais, l'autre moitié, soit de L.E.675, restant à la charge de la Mu- nicipalité, qui aurait en outre à supporter les frais des travaux de terrassement entre les deux points précités."
"Au lieu de payer à la Compagnie la somme de L.E.675, la Municipalité pourrait suivre le mode suivant proposé par M.Lumbroso:"

1e Elle se chargerait d'exécuter les terrasse- ments qui incombaient à la Compagnie entre la rue Chatby (rue de la colonne de Khartoum) et le Pont du Canal. Le prix de ces travaux (2.600m3) est évalué par la Compagnie à... ... ... L.E. 250
2e La Municipalité con- sentirait à la Compagnie une réduction sur le prix de vente du terrain, qui ser- vira pour l'érection de la gare, équivalente à... ... ... " 425
Ensemble... ... ... L.E. 675

"Si la municipalité accepte ces propositions, que je me permets de trouver excellentes, elle aurait à dépenser, pour mettre les rues ac- tuelles à l'axe et au niveau de la route Alexandrie Ibrahimieh, les sommes suivantes:"
a) Terrassements entre la rue Chatby et le Pont du Canal, 2.600m3 à P.T. 3 ... ... ... L.E. 78 au lieu de L.E. 250.
b) Terrassement général, m3 24.500 à P.T. 3... ..." 735.
Ensemble pour travaux de terrassement... ... ... L.E. 813 Réduction sur le prix du terrain de la gare... ..." 425 Total... ... L.E. 1.238
"Avec cette somme les voies du tramways de Ramleh seront posées à l'axe et au niveau de la route de 30m."
Il est bien entendu que dans ce prix n'est pas comprise l'exécution de cette route sur toute sa largeur, mais celle de la largeur con- tenant les voies."

On le voit, le rapporteur se borne à exposer les détails de la dépense, sans dire un mot de l'utilité de cette dépense. Dans ces conditions, nous ne croyons pas dépasser les limites de nos droits en demandant à la Municipalité qu'elle veuille bien, avant de mettre ce projet à exécution, exposer au Ministère et au pu- blic alexandrin les raisons qui militent en sa faveur, attendu surtout qu'il est considéré par tout le monde comme évidemment contraire à l'hygiène et à l'esthétique de la ville.

div.head: DERNIERE HEURE
div.p: (Clôture de la Bourse Khédiviale 1h. p.m.)
Cours de l'Association des Courtiers en Marchandises

The irrigation of Mesopotamia, by which it is hoped to restore the prosperity of the ancient granary of the world, is now being seriously discussed in London and Constantinople. Sir William Willcocks, the late Director General of Reservoirs in Egypt, who is now in London, has brought the gigantic scheme within the sphere of practical politics.

Sir William Willcocks has made exhaustive inquiries in the land of the Twin Rivers, has has collected most of the necessary data, and has divided up the coutnry between Tekrit and the head of the Persian Gulf into some fifteen sections, which can be dealt with one after another, or simultaneously, according to the amount of capital available. The whole area includes over 40,000 square miles of alluvial soil, every square yard of which is capable of being irrigated and cultivated. The general scheme includes the improvement of the Tigris and the Euphrates as means of transportation, and the utilisation of canals for the same pur- pose.

At the present moment only an insconsiderable portion of this rich Delta is under cultiva- tion, and the means of transportation are alto- gether inadequate. To carry out the scheme, proposed by Sir William Willcocks, all taht is required is capital and the permission of the Turkish Government. The supply of capital is, of course, dependent upon the granting of concession.

We understand that the British Govern- ment is well disposed towards the scheme and will support it at Constantinople, though at present the matter has not passed the preliminary stages. Unfortunately, although Sir William Willcocks himself refuses to take a political view of the case, it is impossible to seperate the scheme altogether from interna- tional politics. The Delta of the Twin Rivers is part of the country to be traversed by the Baghdad Railway, it is, therefore, a portion of the territory which Germany is gradually coming to regard as her sphere of influence. No argument is necessary to show that the financial propsects of the railway would be vastly improv- ed by the irrigation scheme; consequently the co-operation of the German Govern- ment should be secured without great diffi- culty. Without that co-operation it is almost impossible to get the goodwill of the Sultan. A good deal of attention has been paid already to the scheme in the German Press, and suggestions have been put forward that German co-operation might be securied if Great Britain were to reconsider her uncom- promising attitude with regard to the Baghdad Railway. The most satisfactory solution would unquestionably be that England should join in the Baghdad Railway, and should control the section between Basra and Baghdad. If an agreement on the railway question could be arrived [illegible] Germany would have every interest in backing the irrigation scheme.

In the meantime, as Sir William Willcocks informed a "Standard" representative, the Turkish authorities are exceedingly well dis- posed towards the scheme. It is the first time that the Turkish Government has been asked to grant a foreign concession for irrigation works-a concession, that is to say, which, besides paying dividends to the conciessionaries, will enormously increase the prosperity of the country, and will enhance the revenues of Mesopotamia beyond recognition. A railway concession, though its civilising influence may be great, has not one-tenth part of the effect on the country and the population that is ob- tained through irrigation on a grand scale in a region[illegible] is made for irrigation. More- over, railways in Turkey have been a continual drain upon the national exchequer, through the burdensome system of kilometric gruaran- tees. The irrigation scheme, so far from being a burden upon the revenues, will increase them tenfold.
When asked by the pressman to explain the irrigation scheme in a general way, Sir William Willcocks replied :-

"Babylonia, or Lower Mesopotamia, was a heavily cultivated and densely populated coun- try for many thousands of years. Its prosperity depended on numerous canals led from the Euphrates and the Tigris, between Baghdad and Basra, past Selucia, Ctesiphon, Cunaxa, Babylon, and scores of other well-known places. The total area of the delta is some 14,000,000 acres, of which 5,000,000 acres must have been cultivated (practically the same area as Egypt). We have a detailed description of the country and its canals in a book written by an Arab, Ibn Serapion, in A.D. 900, and translated by Mr. Guy le Strange. The translation is to be found in the Journal of the Royal Asiatic So- ciety for 1895. Between A.D. 1200 and 1300 the country was over-run by Mongols, and again about 1400 by Tartars, and utterly ruin- ed. while, to complete the catastrophe, the Tigris changed its course north and south of Baghdad, and threw the country into complete confusion. I propose to bring back a state of affairs which will make this delta as rich as Egypt and one of the great cotton producers of the world."
"What objection have the Germans to the resurrection of this country, which would make the Baghdad railway a financial success?"

"The reasons are political, and, as an irrigation engineer, interested in reclaiming the country, I have nothing to do with politics. I have work- ed abroad all my life, and just as while I ate Indian salt I considered myself an Indian, and while I ate Egyptian salt I considered myself an Egyptian, so, if I were to eat Turkish salt, I should consider myself a Turk. Whether England finds the money, or Germany, or
France, or all three together, is a matter of indifference to me; my interests would be those of Turkey."
"But politics must enter into a question of this kind?"

"Yes, unfortunately, it must, but politicians and meteorologists agree on this point-that those who know least are the most confident in predictions. Irrigation is an exact science, and those who know most are justified in being most confident."
"Are you personally confident in the success of the enterprise?"

"I have some authority for my opinion, as I have been directly engaged in irrigation and agriculture for over thirty years in India and Egypt, one on either side of Mesopotamia, and almost in the same latitude. I consider that Mesopotamia will be the Johannesburg of irrigation. The agricultural wealth of that country will be one of the facts of the twen- tieth century. At a moderate calculation, there are £250,000,000 of money in that land. And agricultural wealth differs from a gold mine in being inexhaustible. Some seventy years ago, Mehmet Ali, the founder of modern Egypt, offered to exchange the Pashalic of Cairo for that of Baghdad. If his offer had been accepted, his Highness the Khedive would have ruled to- day a country richer than Egypt. In seventy years the population of Egypt has increased from 2,500,000 to over 10,000,000. The day the politicians allow the reclamation works to be carried out there will be an outlet for agri- cultural irrigation, and pumping machinery which will find work for many a factory hand in Europe and cotton for many a loom."

With reference to Lord Muskerry's question in the House of Lords, asking whether it was a fact that the Hamburg-American Steamship Line intended to start a service of steamers on the Nile, the company informs Reuter's Berlin correspondent that such is its intention. The company adds that it is astonished that such a question should have been put in the House Lords, inasmuch as the company is unaware that a monopoly is claimed for the British flag on the Nile.

For two years excavations have been in progress at Deir El-Bahari, which have resulted in the clearing of two-thirds of the Eleventh Dynasty temple. A large number of interesting relics have been unearthed, but not yet has it been found possible to discover the tomb itself of King Neb-hapet-Ra Mentohetep (III.), whose funeral temple this was. It is hoped that next season's researches may bring about this discovery. Meanwhile, with the aid of the Egypt Exploration Fund, good progress has been made with the work, as is evidenced by the exhibition of antiquities found by Dr. Edouard Naville and Mr. R.H.Hall. The objects in question are on view during the present month in the library of the Society of Archaeology, 37, Great Russel-street, and should certainly be seen by all Egyptologists. The eleventh Dynasty may be fixed roughly at about 2500 B.C., and the excavations lately made show that the temple which lies to the south of the great one built by Queen Hat- shepsu, within the cliff circus of Deir-el-Bahari -had for its chief feature a square erection of heavy stones, faced with fine limestone, which appears to have formed the base of a small pyramid, similar to those depicted in the vignettes of the Book of the Dead. Surrounding the pyramid was an ambulatory, or colonnade, of octagonal columns, the outer wall of which was decorated with reliefs, not a few fragments of which are now exhibited. The lower colon- nades were also adorned with reliefs typical of the lately discovered art of the Eleventh Dynasty, and some of which depict the king's exploits in war and at the chase. There is strong presumption that these reliefs were the work of one Mertisen, who was the chief artist of Nebhapet-Ra's reign, and who is believed to have been the pioneer in the renas- cence of Egyptian art at the epoch of the Eleventh Dynasty, while other fragments shown are attributed to his son. Among the most remarkable of the reliefs brought to England may be noted fragments from the shrines of the priestesses-two of scenes representing King Mentuhetep and his wife being particularly interesting, by reason principally of the exquis- itely carved hieroglyphics and the astonishing preservation of the colour.

Ten of the leading insurance companies of Chicago taking life risks have agreed to revise their mortality tables "in favour of big, active, muscular men, as against fat and spare men." The change in premium rates based on this dis- crimination is not confined to Chicago, but is really a national movement, inspired by the medical examiners of life insurance companies. According to the old mortality averages, lean men were preferred by the majority of the com- panies, but two decades of collecting statistics, on the general average of life, have induced the examiners to favor heavy, active men, and leave lean men in a state of doubt. The figures now available undoubtedly show that lean men are nervous, worry too much, and get tu- berculosis.

div.head: AMERICAN COTTON SCANDAL.
STATE OFFICIAL DISMJISSED
div.p: Public confidence in the Agricultural De- partment at Washington has been rudely shaken by Secretary Wilson's report touching the cotton statistics, which reveals an amazing scandal in official life. This report, which was published on Saturday, shows that there have been leakages in the Government forecast of the crop prospects, which enabled some people who paid for the information to get rich quickly without risk, and also explains the distrust openly evinced by cotton men in the Agricultural Department's figures. It will be recalled that a surprising set of figures, in contradiction of the former month's estimate concerning the cotton prospects, led to a panic on the Cotton Exchange here last Monday, followed by a somewhat similar state of affairs in Liverpool on the following day.

This naturally excited attacks upon the Agricultural Department, concerning whose work in the matter an inquiry was then pro- ceeding. The statement now presented shows conclusively that the Government cotton crop reprots have been furnished to brokers in New York in advance of official publication. It is found, indeed, that not only have the cotton reports leaked out, but the real figures were juggled by venal employés with the express purpose of affecting the market. In this report Edwin Holmes, assistant statistician of the department, is made the culprit and dismissed. Information that Holmes "amassed considewrable wealth since occupying a position of trust in the Agricultural Department" excites no surprise.

Mr. Theodore Price, a cotton broker who made a big fortune out of the recent turns in the market, is vaguely named in the report as having been a beneficiary of "leaks," but he indignantly denies any complicity, or being in any manner connected with any conspiracy. He talked yesterday of bringing a suit for criminal libel against the Secretary of Agri- culture, and was in consultation with his attorney on the subject.

Mr. Van Riper, a broker, who gave Secretary Wilson evidence upon which the report was based, intimated that his confidence has been betrayed, and he has called upon Mr. Wilson to give all the statements he made in the case, and not merely a part.

It is believed here that the cotton scandal is only beginning, and that further investiga- tion will show the usefulness of the Agricul- tural Department to be a thing of the past. Not only cotton, but other matters are at stake. The mere dismissal of Edwin Holmes, without an attempt at prosecution for conspi- racy, breeds great suspicion. It is openly stated that Holmes is let off lightly, to prevent him telling what he knows about other officials. Holmes's profits from his dealings with one broker alone are believed to be upwards of £15,000.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: Major and Brevet Lieutenant-Colonel the Hon. Charles G. Fortescue, C.M.G., D.S.O., Rifle Brigade, second in command of the 1st Battalion at Malta, has been promoted to brevet colonel. Colonel Fortescue, who is the sixth son of Earl Fortescue, served with distinction in the Burmese War, 1888-9, (medal with clasp); Gold Coast Campaign, 1897-98 (C.M.G., brevet-lieutenant colonelcy, medal with clasp); and in the South African War as a brigade major (medal with clasps).

The order for Lieutenant B.C. Bromhead, Royal Berkshire Regiment, to join the 2nd Battalion in Egypt, has been cancelled, and he will remain with the 1st Battalion at Dublin, to which he was attached some weeks ago on return from service with the South African Constabulary.

Some forty subalterns of the Royal Garrison Regiment have been transferred to various regiments as supernumeraries. Thes transferes are effected in the 1st, 2nd, 3rd, and 4th Battalions in South Africa. Only one or two transfers have been made in the 5th Battalion in Canada.

A curious incident, which caused some comment, occurred at Aldershot the other day. In the course of some field operations a brigade of the Foot Guards fell back over Normanby Common. The cavalry was ordered to pursue and charge the retiring infantry, and that they did with a vengeance. The charge was carried too far, and the dragoons rode down on the infantry, smashing up the cyclists, whose machines were destroyed or injured, and slah- ing at them with their swords, whilst the troopers riding on their flanks discharged their carbines, the wadding of which hurt some men. One officer's horse was badly hurt by a sword slash and a sergeant, in protecting himself, had the sight protecter cut off his rifle

it is an open secret that the forthcoming naval manoeuvers will be carried out with an eye to a possible German invasion, a project which finds much favor apparently in the papers of the Fatherland. In any case Great Britain inside of twenty-four hours is now in a position, thanks to the new system of distribu- tion and partially mobilised reserve fleets, to concentrate a tremendous naval force on any threatened point on her coast lines. A few years ago a German invasion was among the most remote contingencies to be provided for,

div.head: ALEXANDRIA SPORTING CLUB
JULY SKYE MEETING.
div.p: Saturday's race meeting on the A.S.C. grounds was dull and uninteresting. It could not well be otherwise in the "dog days," when the ranks of race-goers are thinned by nume- rous departures for Europe. The attendance was poor and the races presented no feature of interest. It was a day for backers, the favorites in almost every case justifying the confidence placed in them. Two of the best stables, those of Khalil Pasha Khayat and Ibrahim Bey Cherif, were not represented at the meeting, owing to the horses being in quarantine in consequence of the discovery of some cases of glanders. This fact undoubtedly made a great difference to the racing. Stillwell was remarka- bly successful with his mounts, winning no less than five out of the six events. A new starting gate, which we believe is the invention of the jockey Whiteside, was brought into use for the first time and appeared to work admirably. It certainly is an improvement on the old start- ing gate, inasmuch as the tape, when released, describes a semi-circle over the horses' heads and is instantly lost sight of by them. The band of the R. Berks., as usual, enlivened the pro- ceedings by a choice selection of music. The following is a description of the various events-

NOVICES RACE of P.T. 1,250, vis; P.T. 1,000 to winner and P.T. 250 to 2nd horse. For Arabs that have never run in a race of any description, Amateur races and Gym- khanas excepted. Weight for age. Distance 3/4 mile.
Mr. A.J. Sursock's ch.a.h. Hotspur, 10.7. Mr. A.J. Michaelides. 1
Prince Omar Pasha Toussonn's g.a.h Shneïnan, 10.3. Bastawissi. 2
Ishak Bey Hussein's g.a.p Mastour, 10.3 Stilwell. 3
Omar Bey Sultan and Ahmend Bey Bakri's c.a.h Zut, 10.6 Hassan. 0
Mr. D.S. Alderson's g.a.h. Venture, 10.7. Owner. 0
Ishak Bey Hassein's b.a.p Beyrouth, 10.3. McCollough. 0

Hotspur jumped off from the start and made all the running, followed by Shneïnan, who ran a good horse, but could never overtake the leader, the latter getting first place easily by a couple of lengths. Time, 1.26.
Totalisator paid P.T. 49 on winner and P.T. 32, 34, and 33 for places

NEWCOMERS' PLATE of P.T. 2,500, vis; P.T. 2,000 to winner and P.T. 500 to 2nd horse. For Arab ponies that have never run in a race of any description, Amateur races and Gymkha- nas excepted. Weight for age and inches, Distance 5 furlongs.
Ishak Bey Hussein's b.a.p. Kamboula II., 9.8. Stillwell. 1
Mr. Donaldson's g.a.p. Derry Boy, 10.3. Fen- wick. 2
Mr. E. Karam's ch.a.h. Tembel, 9.13. Michaeli- des, Jun. 3
Mr. R.L. McCollough's g.a.p Flashlight, 9.13. Abdallah. 0
Saleh Bey Yaghen's g.a.p Ibrahimieh, 9.13. Bonser. 0

After a bad start, Derry Boy and Ibrahimieh made most of the running till entering the straight, when Ibrahimieh was done with and Kamboula II. joined in the lead, Tembel keep- ing close company. A good race up the straight- ended in first place being awarded to Kamboula II., with Derry Boy second and Tembel third. The latter would no doubt have got the race had he not swerved to the left on to the sand and thus escaped the judge's eye. Time, 1.9.
Totalisator paid P.T. 51 on winner, and P.T. 22, 19, and 31 for places.
TRIAL PLATE of P.T. 2,500, vis; P.T. 2,000 to winner and P.T. 500 to 2nd horse. For Arabs that have never won a race of the net value of L.E. 20 or more. Weight for age. Distance 1 mile.
Ishak Bey Hussein's ch.a.h El Tahawi, 10.5. Stillwell. 1
Messrs. Nicolas Soussa and Kamel Effendi Maher's g.a.g. Social Life, 10.4. Kamel Effendi. 2
Moh. Pasha Chehim's b.a.h. Aeolus, 10.0. Mr. A.J.Michaelides. 3
Mr. Hemp's b.a.h. Grand Slam, 10.7. Capt. Roberts. 0
Saleh Sey Yeghen's g.a.h. Wassal, 10.5. Aly Selim. 0
Capt. G.B. Byrne's g.a.h. Mahmoud, 10.7. Capt. Kennedy. 0

The field were dispatched to a good start, of which Aeolus got the best. He maintained a good lead, followed by Grand Slam and El Tahawi, Social Life lying last. At the five fur- long post El Tahawi took up the lead, and was first out of the cutting, with Social Life and Aeolus in close attendance. In the straight Stillwell on El Tahawi had the race in his own hands and won in a common canter from Social Life by a length and a half. Time, 1.53.
Totalisator paid P.T. 31 on winner and P.T. 23, 31, and 23 for places.

PONY STAKES of P.T. 2,500 vis; P.T. 2,000 to winner and P.T. 500 to 2nd horse. For Arab ponies that have never won a race of the net value of L.E. 20 or more. Weight for age and inches. Distance 3/4 mile.
Ishak Bey Hussein and Hassan Bey Kheir el Din's ch.a.p. Lahek (late Raïs), 10.7. Still- well. 1
Mr. J. Chalom's g.a.p. Temsah, 10.7. Kou- kides. 2
Mr. A.J. Sursock's g.a.p. Ilaros, 10.3. Elias. 3
Ishak Bey Hussein's b.a.p. Faik, 10.7. Abdallah. 0
Prince Omar Pasha Toussoun's b.a.p. Hadban, 7.13. Bastawissi. 0
Mr. Ed. Bustros' g.a.h. Nimr, 10.3. Mohamed. 0
Mr. J.N. Simonds' b.a.p. The Bard, 10.7. Fenwick. 0
Mohar. Pasha Chenim's b.a.p. Cupid, 10.6. Lambro 0
Mr. E. Karam's g.a.p. Bayard, 9.4. Mi- Chaelides, Jun. 0

Lahek jumped off with the lead and made all the running, winning hands down by about 10 lengths. There was an interesting race for second place between Temsah and Ilaros, end- ing in a victory for the former. Time, 1.53
Totalisator paid P.T. 38 on winner, and P.T. 28, 34, and 106 for places.

JULY PLATE of P.T. 1,250, vis; P.T. 1,000 to the winner and P.T. 250 to 2nd horse. For Arabs that have not won a race of the net value of P.T. 5,000 since the 1st April 1905. Weight for age with penalties. Distance round the course.
Ishak Bey Hussein's c.a.h. El Tahawi, 9.5. Stillwell. 1
Ishak Bey Hussein's b.a.h. Saiad, 9.7. Fen- wick. 2
Moh. Pasha Chenim's g.a.g. Mizzaud, 9.4. Lambro. 3
Mr. N. Soussa and Kamel Effendi Maher's g.a.g. Social Life, 9.4. Kamel Effendi 0
Mr. E. Bustros' ch.a.h. Malgré Tout. 9.7 Mohamed. 0
Saleh Bey Yaghen's g.a.h. London, 10.0. 0
Mr. D.S. Alderson's g.a.h. Venture, 10.0. Owner. 0

Mizzaud was the first to get away from a fairly good start and led, with the rest of the field in a cluster behind, except London, who trailed off last. At the mile post El Tahawi challenged the leader but Mizzaud still maintain- ed the lead, and on coming into the straight the pair were running neck and neck, with Saïad making up. In the straight Mizzaud was done with and El Tahawi took up the lead and won by a length from Saïad, who drew past Mizzaud on nearing the postk, beating him by half-a-length. Time, 2.32 1/2.
Totalisator paid P.T. 33 on winner, and P.T. 23, 34, and 22 for places.

TROPICAL PLATE of P.T. 1,250, vis; P.T. 1,000 to winner and P.T. 250 to 2nd horse. For Arab ponies that have not won a race of the net value of P.T. 5,000 since the 1st April 1905. Weight for age and inches with penalties. Distance round the course.
Ishak Bey Hussein's b.a.p. Sharour. 9.7. Still- well. 1
Ishak Bey Hussein and Hassan Bey Kheir El Din's ch.a.p. Lahek (late Raís), 9.7. Fen- wick. 2
Moharrem Pasha Chehim's g.a.h. Agib, 10.0. Lambro. 3
Mr. A.J. Sursock's b.a.h. Sans Pareil. 10.0. Mr. A.J. Melchaelides. 0
Saleh Bey Yaghen's b.a.h. Nouri, 9.7. Bonser. 0

Lahek led at the start, followed by Shahrour and Nouri, until the mile post, when Shahrour passed Lahek and led by several lengths, the others being in a procession. Shahrour led in and out of the cutting and never being over- taken beat his stable companion as he liked, this making Stillwell's fifth successive victory. Agib was a bad third. Time, 2.32 1/2.
Totalisator paid P.T. 31 on winner and P.T. 19, 30, and 51 for places.

div.head: British Chamber of Commerce.—
div.p: We would call the attention of persons interested in Egyptian trade to the work of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt, whose office in Alexandria gives information as to standings trade, &c., to its members, and whose monthly publication reviews our commerce. The annual subscription is 11 and all British traders should become members. Our London office, 36, New Broad- street E.C., acts as London agency to the Chamber.

div.head: AGRICULTURAL BANK OF EGYPT.
New Issue of Shares for Increase of Capital.
div.p: IN PURSUANCE of an Extraordinary Ge- neral Meeting held on the 18th May 1905, the Board of Directors of the Agricultural Bank of Egypt offer 248,000 new shares of the said Bank of Five pounds sterling each. These shares will constitute an increase of the Capital of the Bank, and are issued in conformity with the Statutes at the price of Five Pounds sterling per share, payable on application.
Application should be made:-
in EGYPT to the Head Office of the National Bank of Egypt at Cairo and to the Branch at Alexandria.
in LONDON to the London Agency of the National Bank of Egypt, 4&5, King William Street, E.C.
The new shares will rank for dividend from the 1st January 1906, that is to say from the beginning of next year.
Every shareholder has the right on applica- tion to an allotment of one new share in respect of every old share held.

All shareholders who wish to exercise their rights must, under pain of forfeiture of those rights, lodge their applications at one of the places named above on or before the 2nd October 1905 depositing their Share Warrants together with the total amount payable, viz: £5 per share.
The President of the Board of Directors, (signed) Elwin Palmer 26218-8

div.head: NATIONAL BANK OF EGYPT.
CERTIFICATS PROVISOIRES D'ACTIONS
div.p: Il est porté à la connaissance des actionnaires de la NATIONAL BANK OF EGYPT, souscripteurs des 50000 actions nouvelles, que les CERTI- FICATS NOMINATIFS sont prêts.

Ces certificats sont déposés aux Bureaux de la National Bank of Egypt au Caire et à Alexandrie, ou leurs titulaires peuvent en prendre possession contre remise des lettres de répartition à partir de ce jour.
Elwin Palmer, Gouverneur. 26236 3-3

div.head: AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication le Dallage de la rue Canal Mahmoudieh.
Le cautionnement est fixé à L.E. 35.
Le cahier des charges est déposé au Bureau de la Voirie où il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Mu- nicipalité avant le 25 Juillet courant.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour à 5h.p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la men- tion: "Soumission pour Dallage rue Canal Mahmoudieh.

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahiers des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 25 Juillet courant à midi.
Tout offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
Le Vice-Président
(signé) Ambroise Ralli 26237 3 3
